access_care_indicator.long_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care. It includes the proportion of uninsured residents and the number of physicians within 30 miles of the community.

access_scores_dentists:dent_2sfca.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
access_scores_dentists:dent_2sfca.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
access_scores_dentists:dent_2sfca.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
access_scores_dentists:dent_2sfca.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

access_scores_dentists:dent_cnt.long_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
access_scores_dentists:dent_cnt.short_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations

daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
daycare_over_4_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.

food_insecurity_and_cost:Child_Food_Inse.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
food_insecurity_and_cost:Child_Food_Inse.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
food_insecurity_and_cost:Child_Food_Inse.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

food_insecurity_and_cost:Cost_Per_Meal.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
food_insecurity_and_cost:Cost_Per_Meal.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
food_insecurity_and_cost:Cost_Per_Meal.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.

health_literacy_estimates:health_literac.long_description: The health literacy composite captures the adult population's ability to obtain, process, and understand basic health services to make appropriate health decisions. Health literacy composite is based on variables of demographic characteristics, health status, and health care use.
health_literacy_estimates:health_literac.short_description: Health literacy composite captures the adult population's ability to obtain, process, and understand basic health services to make appropriate health decisions
health_literacy_estimates:health_literac.statement: The health literacy composite for {features.name} is {value}.

health_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
health_opportunity_indicator.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
health_opportunity_indicator.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

hhs:childrens_hospitals_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a children's hospital from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. Hospital locations are from the U.S. Health and Human Services. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
hhs:childrens_hospitals_min_drivetime.long_name: Drive time to nearest children's hospital
hhs:childrens_hospitals_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest children's hospital.

sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility
sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

hhs:childrens_hospitals_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a children's hospital from {features.name}'s block group centroids on average.

hhs:childrens_hospitals_per_100k.long_description: Number of children's hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) children's hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
hhs:childrens_hospitals_per_100k.short_description: Number of children's hospital beds per 100k people.

hhs:hospitals_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a hospital from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. Hospital locations are from the U.S. Health and Human Services. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
hhs:hospitals_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest hospital.

sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility
sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

hhs:hospitals_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a hospital from {features.name}'s block group centroids on average.

hhs:hospitals_per_100k.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
hhs:hospitals_per_100k.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.

kotelchuck_apncu_index:adequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
kotelchuck_apncu_index:adequate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
kotelchuck_apncu_index:adequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

kotelchuck_apncu_index:adequate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as adequate in {features.name}.

kotelchuck_apncu_index:adequate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving adequate prenatal care.  Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

kotelchuck_apncu_index:inadequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

schools_2year_per_100k.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_per_100k.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 26, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.

schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with physical science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 40) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 40, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.long_name: 2-year physical science programs per 100k people over 14
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with physical science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.

School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.

segregation_indicator.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.
segregation_indicator.short_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities.

subs_3sfca.long_description: Substance use/behavioral health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
subs_3sfca.long_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
subs_3sfca.short_description: Index of substance use/behavioral health services availability based on supply and demand of facilities
subs_3sfca.short_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability
